front.title: OpenID Connect Dynamic Client Registration 1.0 - draft 08

abstract.t: OpenID Connect 1.0 is a simple identity layer on top of the OAuth 2.0 protocol. It allows Clients to verify the identity of the End-User based on the authentication performed by an Authorization Server, as well as to obtain basic profile information about the End-User in an interoperable and RESTful manner.
This specification is the "Dynamic Client Registration" part of the suite that defines how Clients register with OpenID Providers.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In order for an OpenID Connect Client to utilize OpenID services for a user, the Client needs to register with the OpenID Provider to acquire a Client ID and shared secret. This document describes how a new Client can register with the provider, and how a Client already in possession of a client_id can retrieve updated registration information.
The Client Registration Endpoint may be co-resident with the token endpoint as an optimization in some deployments.

section.title: Requirements Notation and Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.
Throughout this document, values are quoted to indicate that they are to be taken literally. When using these values in protocol messages, the quotes MUST NOT be used as part of the value.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: This specification uses the terms "Access Token", "Refresh Token", "Authorization Code", "Authorization Grant", "Authorization Server", "Authorization Endpoint", "Client", "Client Identifier", "Client Secret", "Protected Resource", "Resource Owner", "Resource Server", and "Token Endpoint" defined by OAuth 2.0, and the terms defined by OpenID Connect Messages 1.0. It defines no additional terms.

section.title: Discovery
section.t: OpenID Connect uses the registration_endpoint from the Provider Configuration Response Sec 4.2.

section.title: Client Registration Endpoint
section.t: The Client Registration Endpoint is an OAuth 2.0 Protected Resource that returns registration information for the Client to configure itself for the OpenID Provider.
The Client Registration Endpoint may accept requests that are not OAuth 2.0 authenticated.
How a developer gets an Access Token to use at this endpoint is out of scope for this specification.
If an Access Token is required for Client registration, the Client Registration Endpoint MUST be able to accept Access Tokens via Bearer Tokens specification.

section.title: Client Registration Request
section.t: Clients MUST send requests encoded as a POST with the following parameters added to the HTTP request entity-body using "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" format:

list.t: REQUIRED. Values client_associate (New Registrations), client_update (Updating paramaters for a existing client_id).
OPTIONAL. The registered paramaters for this client_id) are updated. Used with client_update.
OPTIONAL. The client_secret used to authenticate requests that have client_update as the value of the type paramater.

OPTIONAL. An Access Token obtained out of band to identify the registrant. This parameter MUST NOT be sent if the Access Token is sent in the HTTP Authorization header as described in Section 7.1 of OAuth 2.0. Access Tokens sent in the authorization header must be Bearer tokens.
OPTIONAL. Space delimited list of email addresses for people allowed to administer the client.
OPTIONAL. native or web.
OPTIONAL. Name of the client to be presented to the user.
OPTIONAL. The URL of a logo image for the client where it can be retrieved.

RECOMMENDED for clients using the code flow with a query parameter encoded response. REQUIRED for clients requesting implicit flow fragment encoded responses as defined in OAuth 2.0. A space-delimited list of redirect URIs.

OPTIONAL. The requested authentication type for the token_endpoint. The options are client_secret_post, client_secret_basic, client_secret_jwt, and private_key_jwt. Other Authentication methods may be defined by extension. If unspecified or omitted, the default is client_secret_basic HTTP Basic Authentication Scheme as specified in section 2.3.1 of OAuth 2.0.

OPTIONAL. A URL location which the Relying Party Client provides to the End-User to read about the how the profile data will be used. The OpenID Provider SHOULD display this URL to the End-User if it is given.
OPTIONAL. URL for the Client's JSON Web Key, used for JWS signing of token_endpoint and request objects. If jwk_encryption_url is not provided it is used for JWE encryption of JWT to the Client.
OPTIONAL. URL for the Client's JSON Web Key, used for JWE signing of token_endpoint and OpenID Request Objects.

OPTIONAL. URL for the Client's PEM encoded X.509 Certificate or Certificate chain, used for JWS signing of token_endpoint and OpenID Request Objects. If x509_encryption_url is not provided, it is used for JWE encryption of JWT to the Client. If both x509_url and jwk_url are specified, the keys MUST be the same.

OPTIONAL. URL for the Client's PEM encoded X.509 Certificate or Certificate chain, used for JWE encryption of JWT to the Client. If both x509_signing_url and jwk_signing_url are specified x509_signing_url the keys MUST be the same.

OPTIONAL. A HTTPS scheme URL to be used in calculating Pseudonymous Identifiers by the OP. The URL contains a file with a single JSON array of redirect_uri values. The Client MUST perform a TLS/SSL server certificate check, per RFC 6125.
OPTIONAL. The type of user Identifier requested for responses to this client_id. The identifiers_supported element of discovery contains a list of the supported user_id_type for this server.
OPTIONAL. The JWS signature algorithm that MUST be required by the Authorization Server. All OpenID Request Objects from this client_id MUST be rejected if not signed by this algorithm.
OPTIONAL. The JWS encryption algorithm required for UserInfo responses. If this is specified the response will be JWT serialized.

OPTIONAL. A space delimited list of the JWE alg and enc algorithms required for UserInfo responses. If this is requested in combination with signing the response will be signed then encrypted. If this is specified the response will be JWT serialized.
OPTIONAL. The JWS signing algorithm required for id_token issued to this client_id. The default if not specified is HMAC-SHA256 using the provided client_secret.

OPTIONAL. A space delimited list of the JWE alg and enc algorithms required for id_token issued to this client_id. If this is requested the response will be signed then encrypted. The default if not specified is no encryption.

section.t: Following is a non-normative example request:

figure.artwork:
POST /connect/register HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Host: server.example.com
type=client_associate &redirect_uris=https://client.example.com/callback%20https://client.example.com/callback2 &logo_url=https://client.example.com/logo.png &user_id_type=pairwise &sector_identifier_url=https://othercompany.com/file_of_redirect_uris_for_our_sites.js &token_endpoint_auth_type=client_secret_basic &jwk_url=https://client.example.com/my_rsa_public_key.jwk &userinfo_encrypted_response_algs=RSA1_5%20A128CBC

section.title: sector_identifier_url Verification
section.t: Providers who use pairwise user_id values SHOULD support this element.

It provides a way for a group of websites under a single administrative control to have consistent pairwise user_id values independent of the individual domain names. It also provides a way for Clients to change redirect_uri domains without having to reregister all of their users.
This is further described in Section 2.1.1.1.1 of OpenID Connect Messages 1.0.

The value of the sector_identifer_url must be a HTTPS scheme URL that identifies a JSON file containing an array containing redirect_uri values. The Client MUST perform a TLS/SSL server certificate check, per RFC 6125.
The values of the registered redirect_uris must be included in the elements of the array, or registration MUST fail.

figure.artwork:
GET /connect/sector_identifier.js HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/json Host: client.example.com
[ "https://client.example.com/callback", "https://client.example.com/callback2", "https://client.other_company.com/callback" ]

section.title: Client Registration Response
section.t: The response is returned as a JSON object with all the parameters as top level elements.

list.t: REQUIRED. The unique client identifier.
REQUIRED. The client secret. This should change with each response.

REQUIRED. The number of seconds from 1970-01-01T0:0:0Z as measured in UTC that the client_id and client_secret will expire or 0 if they do not expire. See RFC 3339 for details regarding date/times in general and UTC in particular.

section.t: Following is a non-normative example response:

figure.artwork:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/json Cache-Control: no-store
{ "client_id":"SlAV32hkKG", "client_secret":"cf136dc3c1fd9153029bb9c6cc9ecead918bad9887fce6c93f31185e5885805d", "expires_in":3600 }

section.title: Client Registration Error Response
section.t: When some error condition arises, the Client Registration Endpoint returns the JSON serialized Error Response defined in section 3.3.3 of OpenID Connect Messages 1.0 in the entity body of the HTTP response using the application/json media type with HTTP response code 400.

section.title: String Operations
section.t: Processing some OpenID Connect messages requires comparing values in the messages to known values. For example, the member names in the client registration response might be compared to specific member names such as client_id. Comparing Unicode strings, however, has significant security implications.

Therefore, comparisons between JSON strings and other Unicode strings MUST be performed as specified below:
Remove any JSON applied escaping to produce an array of Unicode code points.
Unicode Normalization MUST NOT be applied at any point to either the JSON string or to the string it is to be compared against.
Comparisons between the two strings MUST be performed as a Unicode code point to code point equality comparison.
In several places, this specification uses space delimited lists of strings. In all such cases, only the ASCII space character (0x20) MAY be used for this purpose.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document makes no request of IANA.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Since requests to the Client Registration Endpoint result in the transmission of clear-text credentials (in the HTTP request and response), the server MUST require the use of a transport-layer security mechanism when sending requests to the Token Endpoint. The server MUST support TLS 1.2 as defined in RFC 5246, and MAY support additional transport-layer mechanisms meeting its security requirements. When using TLS, the Client MUST perform a TLS/SSL server certificate check, per RFC 6125.
